I know of 2 types of "year rounds" in the US. Here they are:
 One is the one talked about in the thread (ex: 8 weeks on, 2-3 off). The other assumes attendance in 3 month quarters: A teacher teaches the same 3 of 4 quarters each year, the student attends the same 3 of 4 quarters every year[Example: Student picks (rather, parent picks): Are you a beach person? be off July/Aug/Sep; a skier? be of Jan/Feb/Mar; family style vacation? take April / May/ June; traveller? Oct/Nov/Dec. Then you attend the other 3 quarters of the year.]
 
 I taught about 30 years. My only objection to "year rounds" was the heat. If it was air conditioned (some areas in schools were), then fine, I'd gladly have gone all year. The kids didn't "lose" thinking patterns over the summer.I didn't need 3 weeks to reteach in the fall. (I would have chosen the more standard 8 weeks on, 2 weeks off)
 
 However, there are other odd systems: one of my student teachers got a job out west and they had the goofy rotating schedule above: He was an avid skier, so he taught from April to Dec.; and every year, the same kids came from April to December. It was a way to allow the building to accomodate more kids (if only 3/4 were there at any one time, then you got more use of it - the 1/4 didn't "overcrowd" the place) However, the community has to really be stable - you can't have frequent "movers" as I did.

Even the older family memebers were in the fields - lots of heart attacks ](my hubby is from a farming family). 
 
 Since we are basically not an agrarian society now, the concept of "year rounds" is totally feasible - provided it isn't so warm, kids fall asleep (not to mention teachers!). If you are in an upscale community which can support something like the 3 mos off/9 on...fine. If the parents support the school, then it is great; they support education & kids are less likely to need reteaching. (In my urban school, this never would have worked)

It is apparent most do not know how the Year Round School system works. A student is not in school for the whole year. Each school or town is set up into a 4 block system. While 3 blocks are attending school, the 1 block is out. It works like this: basically 3 months in school, 3 weeks off, for the whole 12 months of the year. This opens up a vast amount of opportunities for the students as well as the teachers! Students can be involved all year in projects or sports, they can catch attend a class during the "off" time if they need to catch up, families are not limited to the summer for vacation time, they are not home in front of a t.v. or video game for 12 weeks during the summer! Teachers are employed all year, they can take vacations though out the whole year, teachers can help students who need the extra help. There is less need for parents to try to find a sitter for 12 or more weeks for younger kids. You people really need to know how the system works before you give you opinion
